Graft: The relationship between the Clintons and the wife of embattled Anthony Weiner grows curiouser and curiouser. Forget sexting; this may be the real scandal. And one senator sees a possible criminal element to it.

Republican Chuck Grassley, ranking member of the Senate Judiciary Committee, is demanding documents from the State Department shedding more light on the private consulting work that Huma Abedin, aka Mrs. Weiner, performed while working for the government, where she had access to top secret information.

Abedin served as former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton's deputy chief of staff, where she earned $135,000 a year. But it turns out she at the same time worked as a consultant to the Clinton Foundation and a New York advisory firm closely tied to the Clintons, one that happens to do business before the government.

Abedin reportedly hauled in as much as $355,000 in consulting contracts while on the government payroll. What she did for that dough is unclear. "The State Department and Ms. Abedin haven't provided a single document that I requested," Grassley said. "Putting up a stone wall raises a lot more questions."

While Hillary's old department stonewalls Grassley's document requests, her close aide Abedin is suddenly taking leave from her current job as head of her transition office, where by all accounts Hillary is preparing a 2016 run at the White House.
Their sudden separation likely has more to do with Grassley's inquiry than Weiner's perversions.

Grassley suspects Abedin was trafficking in political intelligence while employed at State. He says it appears the Clinton consulting shop — Teneo Holdings — was "compensating Ms. Abedin for gathering information from government sources for purpose of informing investment decisions," a potentially serious conflict.
Teneo's Wall Street clients have included MF Global, as it was collapsing. It also represents foreign governments.

Teneo, which maintains offices in Dubai and Beijing, was founded in 2011 by former State Department official and Hillary 2008 fundraiser Declan Kelly, as well as former Clinton aide Douglas Band and Paul Keary, former senior managing director of FTI Consulting, a global consulting firm specializing in China.

FTI's man in Washington, Jackson Dunn, served as an aide to both Bill and Hillary Clinton, as well as to former Sen. John Kerry, who succeeded Hillary at State. Teneo's "intelligence CEO" is James Shinn, a former Pentagon official focused on China.

Band worked in the White House for Bill Clinton, who happens to be a well-paid adviser to Teneo. Band, who now also works in Clinton's Harlem office and for the Clinton Foundation, is the former president's right-hand man.

Grassley wants to know what, if any, business Teneo was doing before State while it was paying Abedin. He's asked for a record of communications between Teneo and its clients and the department. He also wants to know if Hillary signed off on her outside consulting. So far, he's been stiffed.
He'd also like to know why Abedin suddenly changed her employment status to "special government employee" in June 2012, which allowed her to leave Washington and work from New York.

That same month, Abedin made headlines when several members of Congress sent a letter to State demanding more information about her family connections to the radical Muslim Brotherhood. While Abedin was advising Clinton, State abandoned its prior policy against official dealings with the Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt and elsewhere.

What other consulting contracts and contacts did Abedin maintain while at State, before June 2012? Grassley has asked for all the private contracts she signed while taxpayers thought they were paying her for full-time government work. But Abedin won't turn over any of them.

If there was nothing improper going on, why all the stonewalling?Graft: The relationship between the Clintons and the wife of embattled Anthony Weiner grows curiouser and curiouser. "Putting up a stone wall raises a lot more questions."While Hillary's old department stonewalls Grassley's document requests, her close aide Abedin is suddenly taking leave from her current job as head of her transition office, where by all accounts Hillary is preparing a 2016 run at the White House.Their sudden separation likely has more to do with Grassley's inquiry than Weiner's perversions.Grassley suspects Abedin was trafficking in political intelligence while employed at State. He says it appears the Clinton consulting shop — Teneo Holdings — was "compensating Ms. Abedin for gathering information from government sources for purpose of informing investment decisions," a potentially serious conflict.Teneo's Wall Street clients have included MF Global, as it was collapsing. It also represents foreign governments.Teneo, which maintains offices in Dubai and Beijing, was founded in 2011 by former State Department official and Hillary 2008 fundraiser Declan Kelly, as well as former Clinton aide Douglas Band and Paul Keary, former senior managing director of FTI Consulting, a global consulting firm specializing in China.FTI's man in Washington, Jackson Dunn, served as an aide to both Bill and Hillary Clinton, as well as to former Sen. John Kerry, who succeeded Hillary at State. Teneo's "intelligence CEO" is James Shinn, a former Pentagon official focused on China.Band worked in the White House for Bill Clinton, who happens to be a well-paid adviser to Teneo. Band, who now also works in Clinton's Harlem office and for the Clinton Foundation, is the former president's right-hand man.Grassley wants to know what, if any, business Teneo was doing before State while it was paying Abedin. He's asked for a record of communications between Teneo and its clients and the department. He also wants to know if Hillary signed off on her outside consulting. So far, he's been stiffed.He'd also like to know why Abedin suddenly changed her employment status to "special government employee" in June 2012, which allowed her to leave Washington and work from New York.That same month, Abedin made headlines when several members of Congress sent a letter to State demanding more information about her family connections to the radical Muslim Brotherhood. While Abedin was advising Clinton, State abandoned its prior policy against official dealings with the Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt and elsewhere.What other consulting contracts and contacts did Abedin maintain while at State, before June 2012? Grassley has asked for all the private contracts she signed while taxpayers thought they were paying her for full-time government work. But Abedin won't turn over any of them.If there was nothing improper going on, why all the stonewalling?
Stocks opened to broad losses Thursday after disappointing weekly jobs data. Leaders were under pressure.
The S&P 500 dipped 0.6%, with Best Buy (BBY), Big Lots (BIG) and Gamestop (GME) posting its widest losses. The Nasdaq slipped 0.5% and the Dow Jones industrial showed a 0.4% decline.
Trade was firm, up 4% on the Nasdaq and 7% higher on the NYSE, vs. action at the same time Wednesday.

Leading stocks were taking hard hits at the open, with InvenSense (INVN) and Nu Skin Enterprises (NUS) off 4% and Questcor Pharmaceuticals (QCOR), SolarWinds (SWI) and Netease.com (NTES) down 3% apiece.
VMware (VMW) managed a 2% gain, climbing 9% past a 102.09 buy point after clearing a cup-with-handle base March 13.

Jewelry retail-wholesale stocks posted one of the morning's strongest gains among industry groups. The thinly traded Movado (MOV) led the 13 stock group with an 8% advance in heavy trade. IBD 50 stock Fossil (FOSL) added 2% in five times its average trade. Standard & Poor's announced Wednesday Fossil would be moved from the S&P midcap 400 index to the S&P 500 index. A date for the change was not announced.

Undersea oil and gas equipment maker FMC Technologies (FTI) took a 4% gain in heavy volume. The Houston-based company announced a four-year agreement to provide Brazil's Petrobra (PBR) with an array of undersea production components valued at $1.5 billion.
FMC is testing support at its 40-week moving average in a two-month consolidation.

Best Buy (BBY) reversed a premarket gain and dropped 6% after reporting Q4 earnings, minus one-time charges, of $2.47 per share, up 25%. Revenue climbed 2% to $16.63 billion. Analysts had expected EPS of $2.16 and revenue of $17.2 billion. The consumer electronics chain also announced plans to cut $800 million in costs, starting with 50 store closings and 400 layoffs in management and support roles. The stock has been mired in consolidation for 23 months.Stocks opened to broad losses Thursday after disappointing weekly jobs data. Stock losses widened at midday Thursday after disappointing weekly jobs data. IBD 50 stocks suffered broad-based declines, but some reversed higher while retailers Best Buy (BBY) and Big Lots (BIG) dropped hard.

The S&P 500 was down nearly 0.9% after opening 0.6% lower. The Nasdaq fell 1% and the Dow Jones industrial average 0.5%. Volume was down 2% on the Nasdaq and up 7% on the NYSE, vs. the same time Wednesday.

Leading stocks were hit hard, with Best Buy reversing a pre-market gain to drop 9%, slicing through its 10-week line. The reversal came after the consumer electronics retailer reported Q4 earnings, minus one-time charges, of $2.47 per share, up 25%. Revenue climbed 2% to $16.63 billion. Analysts had expected EPS of $2.16 and revenue of $17.2 billion.

The company also announced plans to cut $800 million in costs, starting with 50 store closings and 400 layoffs in management and support roles. The stock has been mired in consolidation for 23 months.
Discount retailer Big Lots (BIG) lost 7% and video game chain GameStop (GME) was down 5%, both dropping below their 10-week lines in heavy turnover.
Meanwhile, cosmetics network marketer Nu Skin (NUS) and Chinese online game portal Netease.com (NTES) were each off 4% in heavy trade.
Questcor Pharmaceuticals (QCOR) was down 2%, rebounding slightly after hitting its 10-week moving average.
Network management software developer SolarWinds (SWI) also pared its losses after sinking 3% at the open.

On the upside, chipmaker InvenSense (INVN) reversed higher, rising 2% after falling sharply in early trading. VMware (VMW), a developer of virtualization software, managed a 2% gain, climbing 8% past a 102.09 buy point after clearing a cup-with-handle base March 13.
Jewelry retail-wholesale stocks posted one of the morning's strongest gains among industry groups. The thinly traded Movado (MOV) led the 13 stock group with a 9% advance in heavy trade.

However, accessory and jewelry retailer Fossil (FOSL), an IBD 50 stock, was down slightly after rising 2% earlier. Standard & Poor's announced Wednesday Fossil would be moved from the S&P midcap 400 index to the S&P 500 index. A date for the change was not announced.

Undersea oil and gas equipment maker FMC Technologies (FTI) was up 2% in heavy volume, paring an early 4% gain. The Houston-based company announced a four-year agreement to provide Brazil's Petrobras (PBR) with an array of undersea production components valued at $1.5 billion.

Z Trim Holdings was being visited by Richard Mayer, former CEO of Kentucky Fried Chicken (YUM) and Kraft Foods (KFT). Mayer was doing due diligence for a friend who was…

Stocks remained in the red early Thursday afternoon on disappointing weekly jobs data. IBD 50 stocks suffered broad-based declines, but some reversed higher. Retailers Best Buy (BBY) and Big Lots (BIG) fell hard. The S&P 500 was down 0.9% after opening 0.6% lower. The Nasdaq fell 1% and the Dow Jones industrial average 0.5%. Volume was down 6% on the…

Stocks pared their losses late Thursday following a sell-off on disappointing weekly jobs data. IBD 50 stocks suffered broad-based declines, but some reversed higher. Retailers Best Buy (BBY) and Big Lots (BIG) fell hard. The S&P 500 was down 0.5% after dropping 0.9% earlier. The Nasdaq fell 0.8% and the Dow Jones industrial average 0.3%. Volume was down 5% on…

9:15 a.m. Update: Economic woes dinged stock futures Thursday, pointing to a lower open for equities. Nasdaq futures tumbled 16 points vs. fair value, S&P 500 futures dropped 6 points and Dow futures shed 28 points.

Overseas markets were vastly lower. Hong Kong's Hang Seng stumbled 7.1% and Japan's Nikkei 6.5%. European indexes fared slightly better, with Germany's Dax shedding 4.2% and London's FTSE 100 dropping 3.7%.

A number of central banks in Europe cut interest rates in order to fight looming recessions. The Bank of England slashed its key interest rate by 1.5% to 3%. The European Central Bank cut rates by 50 basis points to 3.75%. The Swiss National Bank and Czech Republic's central bank also lowered rates.

On the economic front, initial jobless claims fell by 4,000 to 481,000 last week, worse than estimates for a decline to 476,000. Continuing claims rose 122,000 to 3.84 million  the highest in more than a quarter-century.
The Labor Department's jobs report will be out Friday. Economists expect a loss of 200 payrolls.
Productivity rose 1% in the third quarter, down from 3.6% in Q2 but above forecasts. Futures trimmed losses following the news.

Though a number of retailers reported dismal October same-store sales, Wal-Mart (WMT) remained one of the bright spots. The world's largest retailer delivered a 2.4% increase in its same-store sales, beating views of 1.6%.
Apparel retailer Buckle (BKE) also bucked the trend. Its same-store sales surged 14.5%, matching analysts' estimates.
On the downside, Target's (TGT) same-store sales slumped 4.8%, worse than estimates for a 2.8% decline. Costco's (COST) October same-store sales fell 1%, hurt by foreign exchange rates.

Meanwhile, Cisco Systems (CSCO) shed 5% in the pre-market on a dim outlook. Late Wednesday, the networking giant reported its weakest profit growth in many quarters, though it did manage to beat views. Sales for the current quarter are expected to fall 5% to 10% vs. expectation for a 7% gain.

Toyota Motors (TM) gave up 9% in the pre-open after is lowered its earnings outlook. Hurt by a strong yen and global economic conditions, the automaker slashed its full-year profit outlook to $5.5 billion, down from a prior forecast of $12.6 billion. Its fiscal year ends in March.
10:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Open Lower On Brisk Volume
Stocks opened lower Thursday on continuing economic worries, tried for a rebound but quickly failed.
At 9:56 a.m. EST, the NYSE composite was down 1.6%, the S&P 500 1.3% and the Dow 0.9%.

The Nasdaq fell 1.4%, dragged down by Cisco Systems' (CSCO) weak sales outlook. After briefly reaching positive territory, Cisco shares turned down about 3%. Still, the loss could have been worse given the magnitude of its outlook.
Volume was tracking higher across the board, especially on the Nasdaq.

FTI Consulting (FCN) gapped down and plunged 16.30, or 28% to 41.78 after it missed views and cut its outlook. Late Wednesday, the provider of consulting services reported a 2% increase in Q3 earnings and a 28% rise in sales, but both were shy of Wall Street estimates. FTI also cut its full-year profit outlook to a range of $2.30 to $2.35 a share from prior guidance of $2.50 to $2.63. Analysts expected $2.60. Revenue is pegged from $1.275 billion to $1.3 billion vs. a previous forecast of $1.3 billion to $1.38 billion. In addition, FTI delayed the IPO of its Technology business.

Big Lots (BIG) dropped 1.80, or 8%, to 21.50 in fast trade. The closeout goods retailer said October same-store sales slipped 0.2% and warned that Q3 income would come in near or slightly below its prior outlook of 15 cents to 19 cents a share.

On the upside, Activision Blizzard (ATVI) rose 0.89 to 11.87 in active trading. After Wednesday's close, the video game maker reported Q3 earnings that beat analysts estimates. Revenue more than doubled, thanks to strong demand for its "Guitar Heroes" and "World of Warcraft" titles. Activision also reaffirmed its full-year sales outlook of $4.9 billion vs. views of $4.58 billion. And it plans to buy back up to $1 billion of its shares.
11:15 a.m. Update: Red Ink Rising: Volatile Week Continues
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTT

The downside picked up steam in late morning, after overseas markets tumbled on a series of interest rate cuts among Europe's central banks and the release of weak jobs data and mixed retail sales reports in the U.S.
The NYSE composite skidded 3.3%, laid low by heavy losses in its energy and technology sectors. The Nasdaq composite and S&P 500 both axed off 2.6%. The Dow slipped 2.3%.
Trading volume ran solidly ahead of Wednesday soft levels, up 14% on the NYSE and 18% higher on the Nasdaq.
Crude futures slipped 6% to below $62 a barrel, continuing the week's volatile performance. Natural gas also jerked lower, down 3% ahead of inventory data due out this afternoon.
Gold grabbed back a large piece of Wednesday' $15 an ounce loss. The euro slipped after the ECB's 1.5% rate cut. The dollar and the yen strengthened.

The computer software designers group logged the morning's biggest gain, largely on a gap-up gain by Ansys (ANSS), which sparked 4.67 higher to 31.19 after topping Q3 consensus views and raising its full year EPS guidance. The engineering simulation software designer is still well below key lines of support in a three-month consolidation.

Electric utility ITC Holdings (ITC) also topped views and raised guidance, then jumped 2.75 to 45.35. Shares have advanced in five of seven sessions through Wednesday. Thursday's 7% jump left shares set to test resistance at their 10-week moving average.

BJ Wholesale Club (BJ) rang up a 1.58 gain to 37.16 on fat volume. The mass quantities retailer reported October same-store-sales up 10.2%. The Natick, Mass.-based company also raised its Q3 EPS guidance to the range of 45 cents to 49 cents per share, above previous guidance of 36 cents to 40 cents. The gap-up gain lifted shares above their converged 50- and 200-day moving averages. The stock is working on an awkward double-bottom base with a possible 42.09 buy point.

On the downside, Charles River Labs (CRL) caved 7.08, or 21%, to 26.82. The clinical trial services provider on Wednesday beat Q3 EPS consensus views, but fell short on revenue and lowered its full year guidance. The stock has plummeted to a five-year low since nailing new highs in August.
1:15 p.m. Update: Punishment Continues In Midday Trade
Pinned by corporate earnings and outlooks, economic data and dismal same-store sales, stocks slumped to new session lows midday Thursday.
At 12:45 p.m. EST, the NYSE composite was down 5.2%, S&P 500 4.2%, Dow 4% and Nasdaq 3.6%.
Decliners swamped advancers by nearly 5-to-1 on the NYSE and over 3-to-1 on the Nasdaq.
Volume was again tracking higher across the board.
Crude oil slumped $4.20 to $61.10 on recession worries.
Recent leaders got hit.

Syniverse (SVR) gapped down and plunged 7.97, or 44%, to 10 in blistering trade. The company, which serves the telecommunications industry delivered Q3 earnings below views. This morning, Robert W. Baird cut shares to neutral from outperform. And Avondale Partners downgraded Snyiverse to market perform from market outperform. Earlier it touched an all-time low of 9.79.

Emergency Medical Services (EMS) dropped 1.26 to 32.91 in heavy trading, as gains from its recent breakout continued to fade. On Wednesday, the ambulance provider cleared a 34.93 buy point from a cup base. But it reversed after setting a record high Thursday.

AeroVironment (AVAV) fell 1.34 to 32.22 in active trading. But it bounced off session lows of 30.51. Still, the maker of unmanned aircraft and electric charging systems came under fire for the third straight session.

On the bright side, Dollar Tree Stores (DLTR) rallied 2.24, or 7%, to 37.82 and regained its 50-day moving average. Thanks to increased traffic and strong demand for Halloween products, its October same-store sales climbed 6.2%. Total third-quarter sales grew 11% to $1.11 billion, above views of $1.10 billion. The discount retailer sells merchandise for $1 or less.
Almost Family (AFAM) tacked on 2.15 to 50.84 in brisk trade. It sits just shy of Wednesday's record high.
3:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Fight Back In Late Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
After sliding to new session lows, the major stock indexes staged a comeback late Thursday.
At 2:46 p.m. EST, the NYSE composite was down 4.1%, up from 5.9% lower at the worst levels of the session. The S&P 500 was off 3.5%, the Dow 3.3%, the Nasdaq 2.7%.
Breadth improved but was still negative. Decliners outpaced advancers by more than 3-to-1 on the NYSE and more than 2-to-1 on the Nasdaq.
Crude oil settled at $60.77 a barrel, down $4.53.
Quality Systems  (QSII) tumbled 4.30, or 10%, to 37.90 and lost its 50-day moving average. Oppenheimer & Co. cut the medical software maker to perform from outperform.
Hittite Microwave (HITT) dropped 1.93, or 6%, to 29.66 and sliced its 50-day line. The chipmaker lost ground despite being upgraded to overweight from equalweight at Barclays.
Qualcomm (QCOM) lost 1.21 to 33.96 ahead of its earnings after the close. The wireless telecom giant is slated to earn 60 cents a share, up 11%.
Financials also suffered. According to media reports, Citigroup (C) and Goldman Sachs (GS) began implementing thousands of layoffs. Shares dropped 6% and 8%, respectively.
Fidelity Investments plans to slash 1,300 jobs, or about 3% of its work force. Another round of cuts is slated for the first quarter of 2009.
Ambac Financial Group (ABK) tumbled 21% after Moody's cut a number of the company's ratings late Wednesday.
5:15 p.m. Update: Thrashing Continues For Stocks, Commodities, Dollar
Major indexes closed hard against session lows after a day of tough earnings news and weak jobs data. Stocks were pressured by commodities, which slid sharply as the dollar firmed for a second day.
The NYSE composite dived 5.7%, the S&P 500 5% and the Dow 4.9%. The Nasdaq composite ended 4.3% lower.
The NYSE's biggest drop came from its International 100 Index, down 7%. Technology and energy sectors fell 6.6% and 6.4%.

On the financial side, American Express (AXP) and Citigroup (C) skidded hard. Intel (INTC) dropped 8% after chief executive Paul Otellini told a Web 2.0 summit in San Francisco the economy was in for a two- to three-quarter recession. "Unemployment peaks lag GDP," news sources quoted Otellini as saying. "We'll see much larger unemployment a year from now."
Preliminary data showed volume closed squarely above Wednesday's light levels. That adds a distribution day to the major indexes, and puts the current rally under pressure.

Stocks also took pressure from commodities, as crude prices caved 6%, continuing recent wild swings. Commodities swooned nearly across the board and the dollar lurched higher against all major currencies  except yen  after a string of interest rate cuts abroad.
In stocks, a few intrepid issues held their ground.
In-home nursing care provider Almost Family (AFAM) tacked on 2.47 to 51.16 in brisk trade. The stock sits just shy of Wednesday's record high, after rising in seven of eight recent sessions.

Dollar Tree Stores (DLTR) rallied 2.71, or 8%, to 38.29 and regained its 50-day moving average. Thanks to increased traffic and strong demand for Halloween products, its October same-store sales climbed 6.2%. Total third-quarter sales grew 11% to $1.11 billion, above views of $1.10 billion. The discount retailer sells merchandise for $1 or less.

Downside stocks included FTI Consulting (FCN), which plunged pounded, plunging 14.97, or 26% to 43.11 after it missed views and cut its outlook. The stock sank as low as 37.80 before coming back some.

Late Wednesday, the provider of consulting services reported a 2% increase in Q3 earnings and a 28% rise in sales, but both were shy of Wall Street estimates. FTI also cut its full-year profit outlook to a range of $2.30 to $2.35 a share from prior guidance of $2.50 to $2.63. Analysts expected $2.60. Revenue is pegged from $1.275 billion to $1.3 billion vs. a previous forecast of $1.3 billion to $1.38 billion. In addition, FTI delayed the IPO of its technology business.

Charles River Labs (CRL) caved 7.03, or 21%, to 26.87 in heavy volume. The clinical trial services provider on Wednesday beat Q3 EPS consensus views, but fell short on revenue and lowered its full year guidance. The stock has plummeted to a five-year low since nailing new highs in August.

On the downside, Charles River Labs (CRL) caved 7.08, or 21%, to 26.82. The clinical trial services provider on Wednesday beat Q3 EPS consensus views, but fell short on revenue and lowered its full year guidance. The stock has plummeted to a five-year low since nailing new highs in August.
1:15 p.m. Update: Punishment Continues In Midday Trade
Pinned by corporate earnings and outlooks, economic data and dismal same-store sales, stocks slumped to new session lows midday Thursday.
At 12:45 p.m. EST, the NYSE composite was down 5.2%, S&P 500 4.2%, Dow 4% and Nasdaq 3.6%.
Decliners swamped advancers by nearly 5-to-1 on the NYSE and over 3-to-1 on the Nasdaq.
Volume was again tracking higher across the board.
Crude oil slumped $4.20 to $61.10 on recession worries.
Recent leaders got hit.

Syniverse (SVR) gapped down and plunged 7.97, or 44%, to 10 in blistering trade. The company, which serves the telecommunications industry delivered Q3 earnings below views. This morning, Robert W. Baird cut shares to neutral from outperform. And Avondale Partners downgraded Snyiverse to market perform from market outperform. Earlier it touched an all-time low of 9.79.

Emergency Medical Services (EMS) dropped 1.26 to 32.91 in heavy trading, as gains from its recent breakout continued to fade. On Wednesday, the ambulance provider cleared a 34.93 buy point from a cup base. But it reversed after setting a record high Thursday.

AeroVironment (AVAV) fell 1.34 to 32.22 in active trading. But it bounced off session lows of 30.51. Still, the maker of unmanned aircraft and electric charging systems came under fire for the third straight session.

On the bright side, Dollar Tree Stores (DLTR) rallied 2.24, or 7%, to 37.82 and regained its 50-day moving average. Thanks to increased traffic and strong demand for Halloween products, its October same-store sales climbed 6.2%. Total third-quarter sales grew 11% to $1.11 billion, above views of $1.10 billion. The discount retailer sells merchandise for $1 or less.
Almost Family (AFAM) tacked on 2.15 to 50.84 in brisk trade. It sits just shy of Wednesday's record high.
3:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Fight Back In Late Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
After sliding to new session lows, the major stock indexes staged a comeback late Thursday.
At 2:46 p.m. EST, the NYSE composite was down 4.1%, up from 5.9% lower at the worst levels of the session. The S&P 500 was off 3.5%, the Dow 3.3%, the Nasdaq 2.7%.
Breadth improved but was still negative. Decliners outpaced advancers by more than 3-to-1 on the NYSE and more than 2-to-1 on the Nasdaq.
Crude oil settled at $60.77 a barrel, down $4.53.
Quality Systems  (QSII) tumbled 4.30, or 10%, to 37.90 and lost its 50-day moving average. Oppenheimer & Co. cut the medical software maker to perform from outperform.
Hittite Microwave (HITT) dropped 1.93, or 6%, to 29.66 and sliced its 50-day line. The chipmaker lost ground despite being upgraded to overweight from equalweight at Barclays.
Qualcomm (QCOM) lost 1.21 to 33.96 ahead of its earnings after the close. The wireless telecom giant is slated to earn 60 cents a share, up 11%.
Financials also suffered. According to media reports, Citigroup (C) and Goldman Sachs (GS) began implementing thousands of layoffs. Shares dropped 6% and 8%, respectively.
Fidelity Investments plans to slash 1,300 jobs, or about 3% of its work force. Another round of cuts is slated for the first quarter of 2009.
Ambac Financial Group (ABK) tumbled 21% after Moody's cut a number of the company's ratings late Wednesday.
5:15 p.m. Update: Thrashing Continues For Stocks, Commodities, Dollar
Major indexes closed hard against session lows after a day of tough earnings news and weak jobs data. Stocks were pressured by commodities, which slid sharply as the dollar firmed for a second day.
The NYSE composite dived 5.7%, the S&P 500 5% and the Dow 4.9%. The Nasdaq composite ended 4.3% lower.
The NYSE's biggest drop came from its International 100 Index, down 7%. Technology and energy sectors fell 6.6% and 6.4%.

On the financial side, American Express (AXP) and Citigroup (C) skidded hard. Intel (INTC) dropped 8% after chief executive Paul Otellini told a Web 2.0 summit in San Francisco the economy was in for a two- to three-quarter recession. "Unemployment peaks lag GDP," news sources quoted Otellini as saying. "We'll see much larger unemployment a year from now."
Preliminary data showed volume closed squarely above Wednesday's light levels. That adds a distribution day to the major indexes, and puts the current rally under pressure.

Stocks also took pressure from commodities, as crude prices caved 6%, continuing recent wild swings. Commodities swooned nearly across the board and the dollar lurched higher against all major currencies  except yen  after a string of interest rate cuts abroad.
In stocks, a few intrepid issues held their ground.
In-home nursing care provider Almost Family (AFAM) tacked on 2.47 to 51.16 in brisk trade. The stock sits just shy of Wednesday's record high, after rising in seven of eight recent sessions.

Dollar Tree Stores (DLTR) rallied 2.71, or 8%, to 38.29 and regained its 50-day moving average. Thanks to increased traffic and strong demand for Halloween products, its October same-store sales climbed 6.2%. Total third-quarter sales grew 11% to $1.11 billion, above views of $1.10 billion. The discount retailer sells merchandise for $1 or less.

Downside stocks included FTI Consulting (FCN), which plunged pounded, plunging 14.97, or 26% to 43.11 after it missed views and cut its outlook. The stock sank as low as 37.80 before coming back some.

Late Wednesday, the provider of consulting services reported a 2% increase in Q3 earnings and a 28% rise in sales, but both were shy of Wall Street estimates. FTI also cut its full-year profit outlook to a range of $2.30 to $2.35 a share from prior guidance of $2.50 to $2.63. Analysts expected $2.60. Revenue is pegged from $1.275 billion to $1.3 billion vs. a previous forecast of $1.3 billion to $1.38 billion. In addition, FTI delayed the IPO of its technology business.

Charles River Labs (CRL) caved 7.03, or 21%, to 26.87 in heavy volume. The clinical trial services provider on Wednesday beat Q3 EPS consensus views, but fell short on revenue and lowered its full year guidance. The stock has plummeted to a five-year low since nailing new highs in August.

Stocks opened lower Thursday on continuing economic worries, tried for a rebound but quickly failed.At 9:56 a.m. EST, the NYSE composite was down 1.6%, the S&P 500 1.3% and the Dow 0.9%.The Nasdaq fell 1.4%, dragged down by Cisco Systems' (CSCO) weak sales outlook. After briefly reaching positive territory, Cisco shares turned down about 3%. Still, the loss could have been worse given the magnitude of its outlook.Volume was tracking higher across the board, especially on the Nasdaq.FTI Consulting (FCN) gapped down and plunged 16.30, or 28% to 41.78 after it missed views and cut its outlook. Late Wednesday, the provider of consulting services reported a 2% increase in Q3 earnings and a 28% rise in sales, but both were shy of Wall Street estimates. FTI also cut its full-year profit outlook to a range of $2.30 to $2.35 a share from prior guidance of $2.50 to $2.63. Analysts expected $2.60. Revenue is pegged from $1.275 billion to $1.3 billion vs. a previous forecast of $1.3 billion to $1.38 billion. In addition, FTI delayed the IPO of its Technology business.Big Lots (BIG) dropped 1.80, or 8%, to 21.50 in fast trade. The closeout goods retailer said October same-store sales slipped 0.2% and warned that Q3 income would come in near or slightly below its prior outlook of 15 cents to 19 cents a share.On the upside, Activision Blizzard (ATVI) rose 0.89 to 11.87 in active trading. After Wednesday's close, the video game maker reported Q3 earnings that beat analysts estimates. Revenue more than doubled, thanks to strong demand for its "Guitar Heroes" and "World of Warcraft" titles. Activision also reaffirmed its full-year sales outlook of $4.9 billion vs. views of $4.58 billion. And it plans to buy back up to $1 billion of its shares.11:15 a.m. Update: Red Ink Rising: Volatile Week Continues
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTT

The downside picked up steam in late morning, after overseas markets tumbled on a series of interest rate cuts among Europe's central banks and the release of weak jobs data and mixed retail sales reports in the U.S.
The NYSE composite skidded 3.3%, laid low by heavy losses in its energy and technology sectors. The Nasdaq composite and S&P 500 both axed off 2.6%. The Dow slipped 2.3%.
Trading volume ran solidly ahead of Wednesday soft levels, up 14% on the NYSE and 18% higher on the Nasdaq.
Crude futures slipped 6% to below $62 a barrel, continuing the week's volatile performance. Natural gas also jerked lower, down 3% ahead of inventory data due out this afternoon.
Gold grabbed back a large piece of Wednesday' $15 an ounce loss. The euro slipped after the ECB's 1.5% rate cut. The dollar and the yen strengthened.

The computer software designers group logged the morning's biggest gain, largely on a gap-up gain by Ansys (ANSS), which sparked 4.67 higher to 31.19 after topping Q3 consensus views and raising its full year EPS guidance. The engineering simulation software designer is still well below key lines of support in a three-month consolidation.

Electric utility ITC Holdings (ITC) also topped views and raised guidance, then jumped 2.75 to 45.35. Shares have advanced in five of seven sessions through Wednesday. Thursday's 7% jump left shares set to test resistance at their 10-week moving average.

BJ Wholesale Club (BJ) rang up a 1.58 gain to 37.16 on fat volume. The mass quantities retailer reported October same-store-sales up 10.2%. The Natick, Mass.-based company also raised its Q3 EPS guidance to the range of 45 cents to 49 cents per share, above previous guidance of 36 cents to 40 cents. The gap-up gain lifted shares above their converged 50- and 200-day moving averages. The stock is working on an awkward double-bottom base with a possible 42.09 buy point.

On the downside, Charles River Labs (CRL) caved 7.08, or 21%, to 26.82. The clinical trial services provider on Wednesday beat Q3 EPS consensus views, but fell short on revenue and lowered its full year guidance. The stock has plummeted to a five-year low since nailing new highs in August.

FTI also cut its full-year profit outlook to a range of $2.30 to $2.35 a share from prior guidance of $2.50 to $2.63. Analysts expected $2.60. Revenue is pegged from $1.275 billion to $1.3 billion vs. a previous forecast of $1.3 billion to $1.38 billion. In addition, FTI delayed the IPO of its technology business.

Charles River Labs (CRL) caved 7.03, or 21%, to 26.87 in heavy volume. The clinical trial services provider on Wednesday beat Q3 EPS consensus views, but fell short on revenue and lowered its full year guidance. The stock has plummeted to a five-year low since nailing new highs in August.BY VINCENT MAOAfter sliding to new session lows, the major stock indexes staged a comeback late Thursday.At 2:46 p.m. EST, the NYSE composite was down 4.1%, up from 5.9% lower at the worst levels of the session. The S&P 500 was off 3.5%, the Dow 3.3%, the Nasdaq 2.7%.Breadth improved but was still negative. Decliners outpaced advancers by more than 3-to-1 on the NYSE and more than 2-to-1 on the Nasdaq.Crude oil settled at $60.77 a barrel, down $4.53.Quality Systems  (QSII) tumbled 4.30, or 10%, to 37.90 and lost its 50-day moving average. Oppenheimer & Co. cut the medical software maker to perform from outperform.Hittite Microwave (HITT) dropped 1.93, or 6%, to 29.66 and sliced its 50-day line. The chipmaker lost ground despite being upgraded to overweight from equalweight at Barclays.Qualcomm (QCOM) lost 1.21 to 33.96 ahead of its earnings after the close. The wireless telecom giant is slated to earn 60 cents a share, up 11%.Financials also suffered. According to media reports, Citigroup (C) and Goldman Sachs (GS) began implementing thousands of layoffs. Shares dropped 6% and 8%, respectively.Fidelity Investments plans to slash 1,300 jobs, or about 3% of its work force. Another round of cuts is slated for the first quarter of 2009.Ambac Financial Group (ABK) tumbled 21% after Moody's cut a number of the company's ratings late Wednesday.5:15 p.m. Update: Thrashing Continues For Stocks, Commodities, Dollar Major indexes closed hard against session lows after a day of tough earnings news and weak jobs data. Stocks were pressured by commodities, which slid sharply as the dollar firmed for a second day.The NYSE composite dived 5.7%, the S&P 500 5% and the Dow 4.9%. The Nasdaq composite ended 4.3% lower.The NYSE's biggest drop came from its International 100 Index, down 7%. Technology and energy sectors fell 6.6% and 6.4%.On the financial side, American Express (AXP) and Citigroup (C) skidded hard. Intel (INTC) dropped 8% after chief executive Paul Otellini told a Web 2.0 summit in San Francisco the economy was in for a two- to three-quarter recession. "Unemployment peaks lag GDP," news sources quoted Otellini as saying. "We'll see much larger unemployment a year from now."Preliminary data showed volume closed squarely above Wednesday's light levels. That adds a distribution day to the major indexes, and puts the current rally under pressure.Stocks also took pressure from commodities, as crude prices caved 6%, continuing recent wild swings. Commodities swooned nearly across the board and the dollar lurched higher against all major currencies  except yen  after a string of interest rate cuts abroad.In stocks, a few intrepid issues held their ground.In-home nursing care provider Almost Family (AFAM) tacked on 2.47 to 51.16 in brisk trade. The stock sits just shy of Wednesday's record high, after rising in seven of eight recent sessions.Dollar Tree Stores (DLTR) rallied 2.71, or 8%, to 38.29 and regained its 50-day moving average. Thanks to increased traffic and strong demand for Halloween products, its October same-store sales climbed 6.2%. Total third-quarter sales grew 11% to $1.11 billion, above views of $1.10 billion. The discount retailer sells merchandise for $1 or less.Downside stocks included FTI Consulting (FCN), which plunged pounded, plunging 14.97, or 26% to 43.11 after it missed views and cut its outlook. The stock has plummeted to a five-year low since nailing new highs in August.

Investors in real estate investment trusts had few opportunities to buy into initial public offerings in 2011 — only five equity REITs successfully completed IPOs to raise about $1.8 billion. There were nine in 2010, and they raised $2 billion . But any investors who plunked down cash hoping for a quick gain last year may wish they hadn't. Share…

The main indexes climbed in higher volume Monday, as consumer stocks led a rally driven by another drop in energy prices. The Nasdaq rose 1.1%. The S&P 500 gained 0.7%, while the Dow industrials and NYSE composite added 0.4% each. Small caps fared best, as the S&P 600 surged 2.3%. Volume picked up across the board from Friday's levels. The…

The deep-water drilling permit freeze has kept companies and workers in limbo for the past 10 months. But pressure is building on the Obama administration to OK new activity in the Gulf of Mexico and other offshore sites. The U.S. government froze new deep-water drilling after last April's BP (BP) Macondo oil well disaster, though the official ban ended in October.…

Stocks dropped in higher volume Thursday, as spirited selling cast the market's short-lived rally into doubt. The Nasdaq tumbled 4.3%, the NYSE composite plunged 5.7%, the S&P 500 5%, the Dow 4.9%. The market notched similar losses Wednesday. Following an 18.5% surge by the S&P 500 in a span of six sessions, one sizable down day looked relatively moderate. Volume…

Stocks fell in light trade Friday, as leaders held firm at the end of an up and down week. The Dow industrials fell hardest, shedding 0.9%. The S&P 500 sank 0.7%, the NYSE composite 0.6% and the Nasdaq 0.2%. Small caps took a milder loss, as the S&P 600 ended the day virtually unchanged. Volume eased across the board, netting…
5:15 p.m. Update: Stocks started the first trading day of March on a sour note following more trouble in the financial sector.
The NYSE composite and Dow swooned 5.5% and 4.2%, respectively. Both hit their lowest levels since April 1997.
The S&P 500 tumbled 4.7% to its lowest since October 1996. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq dropped 4%, but remained above its November trough.
Volume fell on both exchanges, but was still above average.
American International Group (AIG) posted the biggest quarterly loss ever for a U.S. company and will get a revamped government bailout package. Shares finished unchanged.
HSBC (HBC) gapped down and dived 19% in huge volume after saying that it needs to raise $17.7 billion. The U.K bank will shut down the bulk of its U.S. consumer lending business and cut 6,100 jobs.
Medical-related issues, which have been a leader in this volatile market continued to deteriorate.
Genoptix (GXDX) dived 20% to a near 52-week low. The downturn left the lab services provider 41% off its November peak.
Omnicare (OCR) dropped 15% on more than twice its average trade. It managed to hold above Thursday's low. The company provides drug services for seniors.
NuVasive (NUVA) gapped down and dumped 13% to a near two-year low on a downgrade. Needham & Co. cut the medical device maker to hold from buy.

On the upside, Compass Minerals International (CMP) jumped more than 7% following a big reversal. The fertilizer and salt maker was down more than 7% at session lows. But it closed below its 50-day moving average.
4:15 p.m. Update: Major Indexes Close Sharply Lower
BY JUAN CARLOS ARANCIBIA
The S&P 500 closed at its lowest level since 1996 after worries about the banking sector intensified.
The NYSE composite plunged 5.5%, the S&P 500 4.7%, the Dow 4.2% and the Nasdaq 4%. Volume fell.
Capitalization woes at HSBC (HBC) and AIG (AIG) rattled almost every industry group.
The metals and energy sectors had the most severe declines amid worries about the global economy.
3:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Off Lows In Late Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks pushed off session lows in late trading Monday, launching what looked to be a solid comeback.
The NYSE composite trimmed a 5.2% deficit to 4.1%. The S&P 500 was down 3.1%, the Dow and Nasdaq 2.8% each.
Turnover was tracking lower across the board.

IPC The Hospitalist (IPCM) tumbled 10% in heavy trading ahead of its earnings after the close. Analysts are expecting 24 cents a share, up 26%. IPC provides management services to medical professionals.
InterDigital (IDCC) slipped 3% and breached its 50-day moving average. It too reports earnings after the close. Analysts see the telecom gear maker's earnings surging 167% to 16 cents a share.

On the upside, FTI Consulting (FCN) gapped up and rallied 13% on strong earnings. Before the open, the company reported a Q4 profit of 58 cents a share, down 3% from a year ago but 4 cents above views. Sales grew 15% to $322.9 million, also above views. FTI guided full-year earnings and sales in line with views and said its board approved a $50 million stock buyback. And unlike many firms that have announced layoffs, it expects to boost staff by 14% this year.
Gold, usually a safe haven, closed at $940 an ounce, down $2.50.
2:15 p.m. Update: Sell-Off Continues: Dow's 6800 In Jeopardy
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks continued to slide in afternoon trading Tuesday.
The Dow came close to breaching the 6,800 level, while the S&P 500 neared the 700 mark.
The NYSE composite dived 5.2%, the S&P 500 4.2%, the Dow 3.6%. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq shed 3.5%.
According to research firm Gartner Group, PC shipments are expected to fall 11.9% this year. Dell (DELL) pared its gain to 1%. Hewlett-Packard  (HPQ) fell 3% and Apple (AAPL) lost a fraction.
Volume was tracking slightly lower on the NYSE and roughly even on the Nasdaq.

Matrixx Initiatives (MTXX) reversed early gains and shed 10%. The downturn sliced the stock's 50- and 200-day moving averages. Analysts see the health care products maker's earnings falling 55% this quarter.
Neutral Tandem (TNDM) lost 6% as it pulled back from a four-session win streak. Still, the telecom service provider remains above an 18.26 buy point from an odd double bottom.

On the upside, AeroVironment (AVAV) reversed early losses and gained 1% in brisk volume. But the stock faces resistance at its 200-day moving average just ahead. The diversified manufacturer's earnings are slated to rise 25% this year.
1:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Extend Losses In Midday Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
Major stock indexes slumped to new session lows midday Monday. Equities have been pressured by worries over the financial sector all session long. Any rebound attempts thus far have been shot down.
The NYSE composite tumbled 4.5%, S&P 500 3.6% and Dow 3.3%. The Nasdaq fell a milder 2.8%. Apple (AAPL) slipped back to negative territory, but Dell (DELL) held on to a 3% gain.
Turnover was again tracking lower across the board.
Financials were among the worst hit.
HSBC  (HBC) plunged 20%, Bank of America (BAC) shed 14% and Wells Fargo (WFC) dropped 13%.
Genzyme (GENZ) gapped down and dropped 7% to a near three-year low. Last week, President Obama called for a framework to approve generic versions of biotech drugs.
Myriad Genetics (MYGN) shed 4% and neared its 50-day moving average.
Elsewhere, crude oil shed $4.31 to $40.45 a barrel. Gold reversed higher, up 60 cents to $943.10 an ounce.
12:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Bleed More, But Techs Such As Apple Hold Up
BY PATRICK CAIN
Indexes continued their downward spiral, but volume stayed lower across the board.
The Dow fell 2.9%, the S&P 500 3.2% and the NYSE composite 4.2%. The Nasdaq was off 2.4%.

Genoptix (GXDX) dived 10% in high volume. The lab service company on Friday fell as much as 11%, then rebounded to close higher on the day. Today's move hasn't undercut that low, but the stock hasn't shown the expected action after such an impressive upside reversal.

Insulin maker Novo Nordisk (NVO) lost 3% as it gapped down for the second straight session. Last week the company ran up to the 10-week moving average, where it found resistance and was knocked down sharply. Today is set to be the fourth straight high-volume loss in a row.
ITT Educational Services (ESI) dropped 3%. The stock is at its 50-day moving average, where it has found support twice in the past two weeks. However, ESI is under its 10-week line.
The tech giants were holding up better than the overall market. Google (GOOG) was down just 1%, while Apple (AAPL) was up by that much.
Athenahealth (ATHN) also was up. The provider of electronic systems for doctor's offices was up 2%. But that was only after it sank 25% on Friday.
11:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Dig Further Into Multiyear Lows
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks hovered near the worst levels of the session after rebound attempts faltered.

The NYSE composite swooned 3.4%, the S&P 500 2.6%, the Dow 2.4% and the Nasdaq 1.9%. Major indexes drove further into multiyear lows. The Dow hit its lowest since April 1997, while the S&P 500 hit its lowest since November 1996.
Turnover was tracking lower on both exchanges.
On the economic front, the ISM manufacturing index improved to 35.8 from 35.6 in January. That topped estimates for a reading of 34.
Construction spending tumbled 3.3% to $986.2 billion, a much sharper drop than expected.
Medical-related stocks again got pounded.

NuVasive (NUVA) gapped down and tumbled 11% following a downgrade. Needham & Co. cut the medical device maker to hold from buy on prospects of slowing growth. The broker also cut NuVasive's earnings estimates for 2009 and 2010.
Amedysis (AMED) gapped down and slumped 10% to its lowest levels since December 2006.
HMOs Humana (HUM), Aetna (AET) and LHC Group  (LHCG) dropped 11%, 7% and 6% respectively.

On the upside, Tower Group (TWGP) rallied 5% after it delivered Q4 results above views. But the stock eased after hitting resistance at its 200-day moving average. The insurance firm's earnings rose 5% to 82 cents a share or 2 cents above views. Sales climbed 21% to $136.4 million, also above views.
Elsewhere, crude oil dropped $3.76 to $41 a barrel and gold shed $5 to $934 an ounce.
10:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Fight Back From Lower Open
BY VINCENT MAO
More worries over the financial sector sent stocks tumbling out of the gate Monday, but they have pared some losses.
The NYSE composite dropped 2.3%, the S&P 1.8% and the Nasdaq 1%. The Dow lost 1.6% after earlier sinking below the 7,000 mark for the first time since October 1997.
Volume was tracking lower across the board.

Some financials were under heavy pressure. HSBC (HBC), which reported a huge yearly profit decline, gapped down and tumbled 19%. Investment firm Knight Vinke warned the UK bank might suffer an additional loss of $34 billion due to bad subprime investments.
Bank of America (BAC) dropped 12%, while Wells Fargo (WFC) shed 10%.

Meanwhile, International Paper (IP) lost 3% after it became the latest to announce a dividend cut. The company will slash its dividend to 2.5 cents a share from a quarter a share. The move will save International Paper about $100 a quarter.
On the upside, Aeropostale (ARO) rose 2% after Goldman Sachs raised the teen apparel retailer to buy from neutral on valuation. The broker also raised its price target to 25 from 22.
Dell (DELL) gained 2% and Cisco Systems (CSCO) added a fraction after Argus Research upgraded both stocks to buy.
9:15 a.m. Update: AIG, Financials Sink Stock Futures
BY VINCENT MAO
Stock futures pointed to a nasty open Monday following more negative developments in the financial sector.
Nasdaq futures tumbled 19 points vs. fair value, S&P 500 futures shed 12 points and Dow futures dumped 94 points.

Insurance and financial services giant American International Group (AIG) reported a Q4 loss of $61.7 billion this morning  the biggest quarterly loss ever for a U.S. company. That translates into a loss of $14.17 a share excluding items, or much worse than estimates for a 37-cent shortfall.
The government will restructure AIG's bailout, including giving it another $30 billion. AIG has already received $150 billion in government help. AIG shares gained 15% in the pre-market.

Meanwhile, HSBC (HBC) said its net 2008 profit plunged 70%. The UK bank has several initiatives to strengthen its liquidity situation. These include a stock offering designed to raise $17.7 billion; plans to cut its dividend and not pay executives bonuses; the closing of most if its U.S. consumer loan operations; and the elimination of 6,100 jobs. Shares tumbled 18% in the pre-market.
PNC Financial Services (PNC) will cut its dividend by 85 cents to a dime a share in order to build capital. It fell 3% in the pre-open.
Among other banks, Citigroup (C), Bank of America (BAC), JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Wells Fargo (WFC) were indicated sharply lower.
Outside of financials, flash memory maker Spansion (SPSN) filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection Sunday. It dived 58% in the pre-market.
In economic news, personal income surprisingly rose 0.4% in January vs. an expected 0.3% decline. Personal spending rose 0.6%. That's the first increase since May and double what economists expected.

3:15 p.m. Update: Stocks pared the bulk of their gains and turned mixed late Friday, despite the House of Representatives passing a revised $700 billion rescue package aimed at helping not only Wall Street, but Main Street.
At 2:44 p.m. EDT, the Nasdaq and NYSE rose 0.2% each. Both were up more than 3% at session highs. The Dow slipped 0.1% and the S&P 500 was mostly unchanged.
Volume turned sharply higher on the Nasdaq. NYSE trade was about even compared to the same time Thursday.
Gold didn't provide a safe haven as the metal settled at $833.20 an ounce, down $11.10. For the week, gold lost 6%.
Crude oil ended at $93.88 a barrel, down 9 cents.

In a second round of voting, the bailout bill passed by a vote of 263 to 171 and will now go to President Bush. Key features of the modified plan include giving the Treasury secretary the power to buy "toxic" assets from financial firms and raising the cap on federal deposit insurance, as well as a number of tax breaks for businesses and the middle class.
Stocks sold off immediately on the news.
Energy Conversion Devices (ENER) jumped 5.23 to 62.29 in fast trade.
It continued to bounce back from a near five-month low. The solar products maker has a spotty earnings record, but profit is slated to surge 431% this year.
FTI Consulting (FCN) gained 2.16 to 70.41 in active trade. The stock slipped back below its 50-day moving average after briefly climbing above it.

On the downside, Open Text (OTEX) reversed early gains, falling 1.78 to 32.11 in brisk volume. The downdraft sliced the stock's 50-day and 200-day moving averages. Thomas Weisel downgraded the software maker to market weight from overweight.
Aeropostale (ARO) dropped 1.43, or 5%, to 28.36. That put the apparel retailer further south of its 200-day line.
1:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Pull Back Ahead Of House Vote
By VINCENT MAO
Stocks remained sharply higher midday Friday, but off the best levels of the session, as investors awaited the fate of the financial rescue bill.
At 12:45 p.m. the NYSE composite was up 2.9%, the Nasdaq 2.8%, the S&P 2.7% and the Dow 2.2%.
Volume was tracking lower on both exchanges. A vote on the bill was imminent.

Global Payments (GPN) gapped above its 50-day moving average. Shares rallied 7.04, or 14%, to 48.10 on busy trade. Late Thursday, the provider of payment processing services delivered fiscal Q1 results above expectations and raised its full-year earnings outlook above views.
Medtronic (MDT) jumped 1.71 to 50.70 and regained its 50-day moving average. The medical device maker won FDA approval to market its LIFEPAK 20e defibrillator in the U.S.

ITT Educational Services (ITT) rose 1.89 to 80 in fast trade. On Thursday, the stock hit a near three-month low, but found support at its 200-day moving average. The provider of post-secondary degree programs reports earnings Oct. 23. Profit is slated to climb 19% to $1.17 a share.
On the downside, Gen-Probe (GPRO) dropped 3.69, or 7%, to 50.87 in heavy trading. Cowen & Co. cut the biotech to neutral from outperform, citing weak sales of the firm's Ultrio blood screener.
Gen-Probe erased gains from the past three sessions.
Urban Outfitters (URBN) lost 0.85 to 28.13 in fast trade. Pali Research cut the retailer to sell from neutral.
11:15 a.m. Update: Indexes Extend Mixed Volume Advance

By ALAN R. ELLIOTTStocks continued to add to gains, buoyed by news of a non-federally assisted buyout of Wachovia Bank by Wells Fargo and as Congress debated in preparation for a second vote on a financial rescue package.
The NYSE composite drifted 2.7% higher at 10:54 a.m. EDT. The Nasdaq composite gained 2.6%. The S&P ran to a 2.4% gain and the Dow rose 1.7%.
Volume was mixed, down 26% on the NYSE and 2% higher on the Nasdaq.
Nine of every 10 industry groups moved higher in morning trade.

November crude oil futures held relatively steady at between $94 and $95 a barrel. Natural gas eased as gold fell hard, down $12.40 to $831.90 an ounce and the dollar launched into a fifth straight session of gains.
A handful of equipment makers moved higher on strong trading volume.
Wabtec (WAB) pulled up 3.05 to 47.52 after a quick touch to its 200-day moving average. The railroad components maker has been consolidating since late August.

Oil field and power transmission equipment maker Lufkin Industries (LUFK) jumped 2.38 to 68.73. The share price remained below the 200-day moving average, after slipping into a correction in early September.
AZZ (AZZ) hopped up 2.92 to 40.24. The electrical equipment and components maker is just below its 10-week moving average, nine weeks into a possible base.

Markets in Asia tumbled. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index wiped off 2.9% as slumping oil prices hammered energy issues and financials slipped on exposure to failing U.S. banks. The Shanghai exchange remained closed for a national holiday.
In Tokyo, the Nikkei 225 slumped 1.9% to a three-year low as automakers, high-tech issues and a broad palette of exporters.
Stocks marched higher in Europe and the United Kingdom. In Germany, Frankfurt's DAX hammered up a 1.1% advance. The CAC-40 in Paris added 0.7% and London's FTSE 100 pulsed 1.1%.
10:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Surge On Mixed Trade
By VINCENT MAO
Stocks opened vastly higher ahead of the House's second vote on the financial bailout plan.
At 9:57 a.m. EDT, the Nasdaq and NYSE composite were each up 2.1%.
The S&P 500 rallied 2% and the Dow 1.3%.
Volume was tracking sharply lower on the NYSE, but much higher on the Nasdaq.
A number of financials shot higher.
National City Corp. (NCC) vaulted 24%. On Thursday, the bank said it will pay a dividend of a penny a share on its Series F preferred stock.
Sovereign Bancorp (SOV) jumped 14%, while Morgan Stanley (MS) and Goldman Sachs (GS) climbed 6% and 3%, respectively.

On the downside, Citigroup (C) gapped down and slumped 2.70, or 12% to 19.80. This morning Wells Fargo (WFC) agreed to buy all of Wachovia (WB), killing Citigroup's deal to buy its banking operations.

Elsewhere, Costco Wholesale (COST) climbed 1.95 to 63.87 following an upgrade. Goldman Sachs raised the warehouse club operator to buy from hold, citing valuation. The broker also raised its price target to 72 from 68.
The ISM services index slipped to 50.2 in September from 50.6 in August, slightly better than estimates.
9:15 a.m. Update: Bad Jobs Data Boost Stock Futures
By VINCENT MAO
Stocks were poised for a sharply higher open Friday, despite a bad jobs report.
Nasdaq futures rallied 21 points vs. fair value, S&P 500 futures rose 18 points and Dow futures climbed 113 points.

In economic news, the Labor Department said nonfarm payrolls tumbled 159,000 in September vs. estimates for a loss of 105,000 jobs. That's the ninth straight monthly decline and the biggest loss since March 2003. Manufacturing, construction and retail saw the largest declines. Education and health services saw some gains.
Payrolls in July and August were upwardly revised by 4,000.
The unemployment rate held steady at 6.1%, as expected. Average hourly earnings rose 0.2%, slightly below forecasts.

Futures actually improved after the bad jobs report, suggesting investors' confidence that the U.S. House will pass the financial rescue plan later today. An interest rate cut might also be in the offing.

On Monday, the House unexpectedly rejected the bailout package, which sent stocks plunging. The bill, intended to prevent an economic slide and help the financial crisis, will get a second chance today.

Wells Fargo (WFC) agreed to buy struggling Wachovia (WB) for $15.1 billion in stock. The deal trumps Citigroup's (C) offer to buy Wachovia's banking operations earlier this week and came without government assistance. Wachovia shares surged 66%, while Wells rose 4%. Citigroup shares slumped 11%.

American International Group (AIG) gained 9% in the pre-market after announcing plans to sell several business units to help repay its huge loan from the government. The company will focus on its core property and casualty insurance operations. Last month, the government bailed out the troubled insurance and financial services giant with a two-year, $85 billion loan.
UBS (UBS) said it will cut 2,000 investment banking jobs in the U.S.
and U.K. The Swiss bank has recorded more than $40 billion in write-downs in the past year. Shares were mostly flat in the pre-market.
The ISM services index for September will be released at 10 a.m. EDT.

Economists expect a reading of 50, down from 50.6 in August.3:15 p.m. Update: Stocks pared the bulk of their gains and turned mixed late Friday, despite the House of Representatives passing a revised $700 billion rescue package aimed at helping not only Wall Street, but Main Street.At 2:44 p.m. EDT, the Nasdaq and NYSE rose 0.2% each. 2:15 p.m. Update: Stocks closed higher in a shortened, seesaw session Friday, capping a week of big gains.

The Dow rallied 1.2% with 23 of 30 issues closing higher. The S&P 500 and NYSE composite climbed 1% and 0.9% respectively. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq rose 0.2% after pushing into positive territory in the final minutes of trade.
Because of the half session, volume was down sharply on both exchanges.
For the week, the NYSE composite surged 13%; S&P 500, 12%; Nasdaq, 11%; and Dow, 10%.
Financials grabbed nice gains.
Citigroup (C) gapped up and surged 18% in heavy trading. The struggling bank continued its post-bailout rebound.
Bank of America (BAC) climbed 5% and Goldman Sachs (GS) 3%.
Black Friday brought retailers mixed results.

The world's largest retailer Wal-Mart (WMT) slipped more than 1%, undercutting its 50-day moving average. An unidentified Wal-Mart employee in New York reportedly died after being trampled by a rush of shoppers.
Urban Outfitters (URBN) dropped 5%, Target (TGT) 4%, and Best Buy (BBY) 2%.
Buckle (BKE), Gap (GPS) and J.C. Penney (JCP) squeezed out small gains.
Among leading issues.
Thoratec (THOR) gapped up, rallied 8% and regained its 50-day line. The medical gear maker will replace Dun & Bradstreet (DNB) in the midcap S&P 400.
Dun & Bradstreet itself gapped up and gained nearly 5%. It, too, regained its 50-day moving average. The commercial information firm will move up to the S&P 500.
1:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Kick In To Grab Mild Gains
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTT
Markets gathered up to turn early losses to mild gains in a shortened, post-holiday session Friday.
Preliminary data showed the Dow notching a 1.2% advance. The S&P 500 rose 1%, the NYSE composite 0.9% and the Nasdaq pulled up from a 1.2% loss to inch ahead 0.2%.
Trading remained light, even when compared with the same time Wednesday. And Wednesday was a slow day.
Advancing issues led decliners by about 2-to-1 on both exchanges.

FTI Consulting  (FCN) rose 5%. The Baltimore-based financial and legal services operation made a second week of solid gains. It's climbing from a correction begun in September. The company will be added to Standard and Poor's midcap S&P 400 index at the end of trading Monday.

Stepan (SCL) jumped 5%, notching its sixth straight day of gains. The move lifted shares above their 200-day moving average and drove them well up the right side of a possible cup-shaped base begun in September.

On the downside, Shanda Interactive Entertainment (SNDA) shed 5%. Analysts expect the Internet gaming operation's earnings growth to slow to 25% on a 51% increase in sales when the China-based company reports Q3 results Monday.
Crude futures held between $51 and $52 a barrel, down more than $2. Natural gas held just above a 12-month low. Gold pulled back after an early surge, trading down a dime near $816 an ounce.
12:15 p.m. Update: Losses Ease As Dollar Firms And Volume Slips
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTTIndexes pulled off lows, with a number of leading stocks as well as beleaguered blue chips posting gains as the dollar firmed vs. most major foreign currencies.
The Dow pulled 0.4% higher with Citigroup (C), General Electric (GE) and Bank Of America (BAC) counteracting losses by Exxon Mobil (XOM)and Chevron (CVX).
The NYSE composite and The S&P 500 edged fractionally onto positive ground. The Nasdaq composite pulled well off its lows, but remained 0.8% lower.
Volume held to its extremely light, post-holiday mode.
About two-thirds of the 197 industry groups tracked by IBD moved lower in the session. Energy groups led the downside. Gem miners and vehicle tire makers posted the strongest gains.
World Fuel Services (INT) moved up 4% to a 52-week high in above-average trading. Shares last week had reversed more than 8% below the 30.28 buy point after a breakout from a six-week cup base.

Denmark-based Novo Nordisk (NVO) gapped up and surged 6%, breaking resistance at its 50-day moving average. The maker of insulin-related drugs and treatments is working to build a floor in a consolidation begun in April.

On the downside, oil tanker fleet operator Frontline (FRO) tumbled 13% after reporting Q3 earnings of $1.76 a share, 20 cents below expectations. The EPS figure excluded a $29.3 million mark-to-market loss on a forward contract. UBS upgraded the stock to neutral from sell.
Crude futures continued lower, down nearly $3 to $51.48 a barrel. Natural gas pulled back 55 cents to 6.33 per million Btu, just above the 12-month low struck Nov. 14.
The dollar strengthened and the euro notched its lowest mark since Monday on expectations that the European Central Bank is likely to lower interest rates next week.
11:15 a.m. Update: Indexes Slip A Notch In Ultra-Light Trading
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTT
Technology- and energy-sector losses held indexes lower in late-morning trading.
The Nasdaq fell 1.2%. The NYSE composite rode a 0.7% loss, just off its early lows. The Dow slipped a fraction while the S&P 500 was down 0.4%.
The NYSE's energy index had that exchange's biggest loss, down 2.6%. Baidu.com (BIDU) and Millicom International Cellular (MICC) posted some of the Nasdaq 100's heaviest declines.
As expected of a post-Thanksgiving session, volume was light.

American Science & Engineering (ASEI) pushed to a new high, up 4%. It's the X-ray inspection systems maker fifth straight day of gains and put it 7% above a 74.15 buy point on a nine-week cup-with-handle base.

Dun & Bradstreet (DNB) gapped up to a 4% gain, pulling above its 10-week moving average for the first time since September. Standard & Poor's said the business information services provider will join the S&P 500 index at the close of trading Monday.
Medical devices maker Thoratec (THOR) gapped up to add 6%. Thoratec will replace Dun & Bradstreet on the midcap S&P 400. The stock climbed back above its 10-week moving average.
Markets in Europe pulled off their lows in afternoon trading and were mixed.
The FTSE 100 in London rose 0.6%. The CAC-40 in Paris edged 0.2% lower. Frankfurt's DAX was down 0.3%.
Hong Kong's Hang Seng finished the week up nearly 10%. Tokyo's Nikkei added 7.6%, its best week in a month.
Oil futures fell more than $2 to $52.43 a barrel, holding near the center of its recent $49 to $55 range.
10:15 a.m. Update: Dow Hangs Tough While Peers Lose Ground
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks opened lower, turned narrowly mixed, then turned lower again early Friday.
The Nasdaq was down 1.1%, the NYSE composite 0.8% and the S&P 500 0.4%. The Dow was mostly unchanged.
Volume was tracking sharply lower on the Nasdaq and a bit lower on the NYSE.
Financials were mostly higher. Citigroup (C) gapped up and rose 12% in fast trade. The bank has advanced four straight sessions after receiving a government bailout Monday.
Bank of America (BAC) and JPMorgan Chase (JPM) each rose 2%.
On the downside, ArcelorMittal (MT) shed 6% after announcing a round of job cuts. The world's largest steel maker will slash 9,000 jobs in response to the global economic slowdown.

Panasonic (PC) gapped down and dived nearly 20% after cutting its profit outlook. Hurt by a strong yen and weak sales, the electronics maker pegged full-year income at $316 million, down sharply from a prior forecast of $3.3 billion.
9:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Poised For Soft Start In Short Session
BY VINCENT MAO
Stock futures signaled a weaker open as equities look to pull back from their recent gains in an abbreviated session.
Nasdaq futures dropped 15 points vs. fair value, S&P 500 future shed 7 points and Dow futures gave up 27 points.

Overseas markets were mostly mixed. Hong Kong's Hang Seng and Japan's Nikkei gained 2.5% and 1.7%, respectively. In India, where stock markets reopened following this week's terrorist attacks in Mumbai, the Sensex rose 0.7%. Meanwhile, Germany's DAX lost 1.4% and London's FTSE slipped a fraction.
U.S. markets will close at 1 p.m. EST. Trading volume is expected to be light.
Retailers will be in focus on this Black Friday. Hit by a waning economy, same-store sales tumbled a record 2.8% in October.
Nordstrom (JWN) fell 2% in the pre-market. Wal-Mart (WMT) slipped a fraction and Best Buy (BBY) rose a fraction.
Chesapeake Energy (CHK) dived 14% on news that it filed to sell up to $1.8 billion in common shares.
Nokia  (NOK) said it will stop selling most of its cell phones in Japan, though it will continue selling its luxury Vertu brand there.

Crude oil slipped 60 cents to $53.84 a barrel. 2:15 p.m. Update: Stocks closed higher in a shortened, seesaw session Friday, capping a week of big gains.The Dow rallied 1.2% with 23 of 30 issues closing higher.
